Description: After a two-year closure, the foot trail that winds through central Curtis Prairie has reopened. There's a new boardwalk and bridge, and the trail was recently graveled to even out ruts formed over years of heavy traffic. We're excited for visitors to explore this special path.

The Arboretum recently received a generous gift from a donor to purchase 240 pounds of native plant seed for use in restoration efforts. And the land care crew is beaming with gratitude! Seeds include hyssop, bottlebrush grass, butterfly-weed, and purple Joe-Pye-weed. Land care staff has also collected about 240 pounds of seed from restoration areas. Seed will be combined into mixes and spread before snow falls. Restoring an area like Teal Pond Wetlands or the Lost City can take years of sustained effort, and donations like this are essential for success and priceless for a healthy ecosystem and visitor enjoyment. 

#ecosystemrestoration #nativeplants #seedcollecting

Join us for our final fall lecture on Tuesday, October 25. Jessika Greendeer will discuss Dream of Wild Health, an intertribal, independent nonprofit in the Twin Cities. Come learn how their 30-acre farm in Hugo, Minnesota, reconnects the urban Native American community with traditional Native plants and their culinary, medicinal, and spiritual use. Note: remote speaker. Event link in bio.
Image Text: UW-Madison UW- Arboretum Fall Lectures 2022 Dream of Wild Health Jessika Greendeer, farm director, Dream of Wild Health Tuesday, October 25, 7-8:30 p.m. Arboretum Visitor Center Free, no registration required

Description:
During Fill the Hill, you can support the Arboretum by giving to the Friends of the Arboretum fund (link in bio). Gifts strengthen our work, including outdoor education for youth and families, teaching about native plants, and engaging the community in urban conservation issues and citizen science. We’re so grateful to our generous supporters, such as Leslie Ladd and Bill Hantke:

“As twenty-year residents of the unique Arboretum neighborhood, we have never taken one moment for granted. We share the same sense of wonder and beauty as all the folks visiting every day. We donate generously to the Arboretum because to us it means ‘home.’” 

#uwflamingos
Image Text: As twenty-year residents of the unique Arboretum neighborhood, we have never taken one moment for granted. We share the same sense of wonder and beauty as all the folks visiting every day. We donate generously to the Arboretum because to us it means "home." Leslie Ladd and Bill Hantke FILL THE HILL

Description:
Fill the Hill is underway! Join in the flamingo fun (link in bio) and make a gift to the Friends of the Arboretum fund. Gifts help sustain our work, from environmental education to ecological restoration to citizen science and more. We’re so grateful to our generous supporters. What does the Arboretum mean to you? Corinne Burgermeister and Pete Schwieger say:

“We’ve grown closer as a family through our Arboretum adventures, learned about nature, and improved our health. We want everyone in Madison – present and future – to enjoy these benefits. We donate and volunteer to support the Arboretum’s programs and growth.” 
 
#uwflamingos
Image Text: We've grown closer as a family through our Arboretum adventures, learned about nature, and improved our health. We want everyone in Madison present and future to enjoy these benefits. We donate and volunteer to support the Arboretum' programs and growth. Corinne Burgermeister and Pete Schwieger FILL THE HILL

Description: Fill the Hill starts at 5 p.m. CDT, and the flamingos are coming back to Bascom Hill! (This one stopped in at the Arb, we’ll give it directions to campus.) Be part of the feathered fun October 20–21. Fly on over to uwflamingos.com (link in bio) and make a gift to the Friends of the Arboretum fund, which helps the Arboretum meet its most pressing needs. Will you join our flock? #uwflamingos
Image Text: FILL THE HILL

Description: The flamingos are back! And this year, it's their tenth annual homecoming. Will you help us Fill the Hill October 20–21? The growing flock represents the support of the extended Badger community, whose philanthropy plays a vital role in keeping the UW and Arboretum strong. Click the link in our bio to join in the feathered fun.

In our second fall lecture on Thursday, October 20, at 7 p.m., Robert Pierce will discuss "Restoring Healthy Food Connections on Madison’s South Side." Pierce is the owner and farmer at Neighborhood Food Solutions (NFS), which engages community about the economic, social, health, and environmental impacts of food, and promotes participation in food- related economic opportunities. His talk will explore how these programs restore Madison communities. Event link in bio. Learn more about NFS at https://www.nfsinc.org/.
Image Text: UW-Madison UW- Arboretum Fall Lectures 2022 Restoring Healthy Food Connections on Madison's South Side Robert Pierce, owner and farmer, Neighborhood Food Solutions Thursday, October 20, 7-8:30 p.m. Arboretum Visitor Center Free, no registration required

Description:
Photographers! Fall color is near and it’s a popular time for family and special occasion photo sessions. We appreciate being a site for these meaningful photos, and we want to share some guidelines to help support and protect all that lives here.

If you’re an amateur or professional photographer doing posed and formal photography, a photo permit is required. We ask photographers and their clients to follow visitor etiquette – leave pets at home, stay on trails and lawns to protect plants and wildlife habitat, and if you’re using props, keep them ecologically friendly (no confetti, glitter, etc.). Drones for recreational or hobby use are not allowed. Thanks for your cooperation! Click the link in our bio to learn more about photography permits.

As fall brings shorter days, go out after dark and enjoy the night sky! Join Arboretum naturalists this Saturday, October 8 for our monthly full moon night walk. Stargaze through pine trees and practice sensing with your ears and your feet. Come prepared for cool nighttime temperatures. Clink events calendar link in bio for more information.

Photo: rkarkowski/Pixabay

We have many events coming up, for a range of interests. Join us for nature walks, a family program, or a public talk. Volunteer your time or take a class. Link in bio for events calendar with details and class registration links.

It's almost October and that means the fall lecture series is coming up soon. Speakers will explore ways of restoring ecosystems, relationships with the land, food systems, and community health. Talks are free and in person at the Visitor Center, no registration required. Link with details in bio.

The 2022 Arboretum Research Fellows recently met with Darcy Kind from the Wisconsin Department of Natural Resources and Mike Hansen from the Arboretum to learn about land management. During a tour in the Wingra Oak Savanna, the group gained a deeper understanding of how management decisions are made. They heard about similarities and differences between public and private land management decisions. These meetings are designed to enhance the Fellows education, networks, and understanding of the Arboretum. See link in bio to learn more about the Fellows and their research.

Our fall lecture series is coming up in October. Speakers will explore ways of restoring ecosystems, relationships with the land, food systems, and community health. Talks are free and in person at the Visitor Center, no registration required. Link with details in bio.
Image Text: UW-Madison Arboretum Fall Lectures 2022 OCTOBER 11 Relationship and Connection- Community and Ecological Restoration OCTOBER 20 Restoring Healthy Food Connections on Madison's South Side OCTOBER 25 Dream of Wild Health 7 to 8:30 p.m. in the Visitor Center

Description: Our team is growing! We’re hiring two full-time staff positions: a data and GIS coordinator to join our research team, and an adult and community engagement coordinator to join the education unit. Applications due September 30. Links in bio.

We have only a few spots left for the September 18 Native Gardening Conference. Enjoy an inspiring and informative day dedicated to native plant gardening. Learn from experts, network with fellow gardeners, and come away with enthusiasm and insight. This year's keynote speaker is Alan Branhagen from the @mn_arb. The conference welcomes people with a range of interests and experience. Sign up soon! A wait list will also be available. Link in bio.
Image Text: Native by Design: Gardening for a Sustainable Future Join us for the UW Arboretum's 2022 native gardening conference

Description: We have two student job openings: a visitor center assistant and an assistant ranger. Students are an integral part of Arboretum operations – come join our team! Visit the UW–Madison student jobs board and search "Arboretum." Applications are due August 29. Link in bio.

If yard and garden fertilizers are improperly applied, excess nutrients can wash into our lakes and contribute to algae growth that gets in the way of summer fun. Learn about steps you can take to minimize your impact if you do choose to use it: https://ripple-effects.com/yardAndGarden. #ProtectOurLakes
Image Text: Arboretum UNVERSITY VISCONSIN MADISON #ProtectOurLakes pua 1 Don't let this turn into this.

Description:
Looking to enjoy nature-based activities together with your young ones and prairie scenery this summer? 

Join us on August 9 for "Learning Together – Animals in the Prairie." Walk by plants taller than you as we look for animals that live among prairie grasses and wildflowers. There is much to discover! This class is for preschool-aged children and their adult caregivers. 

Come explore! Events calendar link in bio.

Raising your mower blade height to at least 2.5 inches can help grow a full, dense lawn. This allows your yard to soak up the rain and helps prevent stormwater from carrying pollutants into our beautiful local lakes. More here: https://ripple-effects.com/yardAndGarden#lawn. #SoakUpTheRain
Image Text: Arboretum UNIVERSIT WISCONSIN- MADISON #SoakUpTheRain #SoakUp TheRain ម Keep your lawn long for beautiful lakes!

Description:
Lets #EndPlantBlindness and meet the ginkgo! This tree has been around for over 170 million years. In the Jurassic age, this tree produced a malodorous fruit that the 🦕 dinosaurs loved. The ginkgo has also been known to survive the Hiroshima nuclear bomb. Today, we can most commonly find the ginkgo along our streets because it is urban tolerant. #ginkgo #uwarboretum #madisonwi #strongplants #urban
.
.
.
This spring, the Arboretum was a “client” for students in a Social Media Analytics class. They visited the Arboretum and listened to unique tree stories told by curator David Stevens. Then they created Instagram posts to tell these stories and address plant blindness. Here is one of the posts created by Maci, Ryan, and Isabel to raise awareness about plant blindness. Story link in bio. @kaipingchen23 @uwmadison_lsc #scicomm #LSC375 #plantblindness

Something special about witch hazel is that its flowers bloom during the colder months. If you need a pick-me-up during Wisconsin’s winter, come visit these beautiful bushes! #UWArboretum #WisconsinNature #WitchHazel #Bloom #MadisonWI
.
.
.
This spring, the Arboretum was a “client” for students in a Social Media Analytics class. They visited the Arboretum and listened to unique tree stories told by curator David Stevens. Then they created Instagram posts to tell these stories and address plant blindness. Here is one of the posts created by Luke, Brooke, Jazlyn, and Zhuoer to share a unique plant story. Story link in bio. @kaipingchen23 @uwmadison_lsc #scicomm #LSC375 #plantblindness

Why does the fruit of ginkgo trees stink? And what does that have to do with dinosaurs? Volume on for the answer. 

This spring, the Arboretum was a “client” for students in a Life Sciences Communication Social Media Analytics class. They visited the Arboretum to hear Longenecker Horticultural Gardens curator David Stevens tell stories like this one about unique trees. Then they created Instagram posts to share the stories and help address plant blindness. A few of the students’ posts are coming soon! @kaipingchen23 @uwmadison_lsc #scicomm #LSC375 #plantblindness

So many native plants are blooming! Here is a sampling: large-flowered penstemon, blue harebell, white wild indigo, golden Alexander, spiderwort, prairie rose, wild columbine, Canada anemone. #winativeplants #prairies #nativeplantgardens #restoration

Not only do rain barrels help prevent flooding from excess stormwater, they also provide a free source of water for your garden! Learn more about purchasing and setting up your barrel here (styles and colors vary): https://ripple-effects.com/rainBarrels. #SoakUpTheRain
Image Text: Arboretum UNIVERSIT VISCONSIN- MADISON #SoakUp MANK TheRain Capture rain from your roof- and moments like this- with the help of a rain barrel!

Description:
#Repost @uwmadison with @make_repost

Ever wonder why you find yourself tiptoeing around an abundance of earthworms on the sidewalk after it rains? Brad Herrick, a #UWMadison ecologist and research program manager at the @uwarboretum, explains this 🪱 phenomenon.
Image Text: × uwmadison

Description: Today's roadside crane family sightings! A crane family strolls down the road, two baby chicks prancing alongside their parents. The other group of four cranes (one is out of frame) is likely a family of a mated pair with two young from last year that will soon go out on their own. #madisonwi #uwmadison #urbanwildlife

Want to contribute to monarch conservation? Sign up for the June 4 @mlmpcitsci virtual training! Learn how to get involved and talk with experts. Register by June 2. Link in bio. #citizenscience #monarchconservation #getinvolved

At Lost City Forest, Arboretum and Edgewood College researchers are studying the effectiveness of combined management techniques to control invasive shrubs and help establish native species. Last fall, volunteers hand-cleared some research plots during restoration work parties, and land care staff forestry mowed others. This spring, Arboretum staff followed up with prescribed fire in select plots. More data will be collected this summer to assess changes in vegetation, leaf litter, woody debris, and light availability in all the research plots including the control plots with no management. #madisonwi #uwmadison #rxfire #research

Blooms update! Magnolias are in bloom (pics 1 & 2), with more to come as the weather warms. Lilacs (pic 3) and crabapples (pic 4) will surely bloom with next week’s warm spell. Pears (pic 5) are in bloom and so are cherries (pic 6). This weekend will be the ideal time to see the cherries as they are likely to fade in next week’s heat. Bloodroot and trout-lily (pic 7) are blooming at Wingra Oak Savanna. The little yellow warbler (pic 8) is here to remind us that it’s every Wisconsin birder’s favorite time of year! #madisonwi #uwmadison #wiwx #springblooms #birdmigration

Once the risk of frost has passed, converting even a small corner of your yard to native plants can make a big difference for our lakes! Their deep roots help rain soak into the soil and protect against flooding. These resources will show you how to get started: https://www.ripple-effects.com/rainGardens. #SoakUpTheRain

It’s true: some magnolias have begun to bloom (photo 1). Buds are protected but blooms are fragile, and once open they can be damaged (photo 2) by freezing temps like those forecast for tonight. Thanks to a cool spring, we are still mostly waiting for things to flower and green up (photo 3). Cherries have not yet bloomed but are close, crabapple buds are swelling (photo 4), and lilacs (photo 5) are likely a few weeks off. Forsythia is ablaze (photo 6). Bloom times, duration, and quality are weather dependent so sunshine and warmth would be a welcome change to move things along. #madisonwi #uwmadison #wiwx #springbloom

Eastern bluebirds are a beloved species and a welcome sign of spring. Join us for an upcoming class to learn about the fascinating life of bluebirds, their behavior, reasons for their decline, and restoration efforts. Instructor Sylvia Marek, Arboretum naturalist, created the Arboretum bluebird trail in 1988 and has monitored it for 33 years. You won't want to miss this class! Fee: $20. Register by May 3. Link in bio.
Waiting out the rain ##madisonwi #uwmadison #wiwx #urbanwildlife
Ah, spring in Wisconsin. Snowdrops and crabapple tree, photos a day apart. Not pictured: mud. #madisonwi #uwmadison #wiwx

Help rain soak into the soil instead of rushing directly to the storm drains that empty into and pollute our local lakes! Redirect your roof downspouts so rain can run into your yard or garden instead of onto a paved surface. Flexible downspout extensions are available at many hardware stores, so don’t wait to make this quick fix! https://ripple-effects.com/ #SoakUpTheRain
Image Text: Arboretum UNIVERSIT VISCONSIN MADISON #SoakUp TheRain UO C Flooded streets: polluted lakes

Description: It is pretty tho #wiwx #spring #madisonwi #uwmadison

Looking to explore seasonal changes and enjoy nature-based stories and art activities together with your young ones?

Sign up for our upcoming family class "Learning Together—Springtime Awakenings." We'll take a walk to listen for birds and frogs, and look for new leaves on trees and woodland wildflowers. We'll also share stories and create nature art and crafts.

Fee: $20 per family/group up to four people. Click the link in our bio to learn more and register.

Come join our team! We're hiring a Horticultural Specialist and a Natural Resource Specialist. Applications for both positions are due March 15.

The Horticultural Specialist will work with the Longenecker Horticultural Gardens Curator to maintain the state's largest and most diverse collection of woody plants. Learn more and apply: https://jobs.hr.wisc.edu/.../512634/horticultural-specialist. 

The Natural Resource Specialist will be a member of the land care crew that works to restore and manage the Arboretum's prairies, woodlands, and wetlands. Learn more and apply: https://jobs.hr.wisc.edu/.../natural-resource-specialist.

Spring is just around the corner. Join us for two upcoming in-person classes to celebrate the start of the season.

In "Phenology—Keeping Track of Nature" on March 19, explore how phenology—noting the periodic occurrences in the natural world—is both art and science, practiced for millennia across cultures and regions. Learn about different approaches, and maybe find your own. Fee: $20.

And in "Ponds, Pines and Birds–Finding Mary Oliver" on April 1, explore the nature-themed poems of Mary Oliver as inspiration to find your own topics to write about from the trail. Fee: $15.

Advance registration is required. See the link in our bio for more information and registration.

Native plants make the best rain gardens, which are important sites where stormwater can soak into the soil. A garden of any size can make a big difference, so check out https://foamadison.org/ or https://www.ripple-effects.com/plantDane to pre-order native plants for pickup in May! The deadlines to order are usually in mid-March, so make sure to get yours in early. #SoakUpTheRain
Image Text: Arboretum UNIVERSIT OF WISCONSIN MADISON #SoakUp TheRain Is your yard ready to bloom this spring?

Description: The Lake Wingra Springs Chloride Monitoring Project began in 2011 to assess chloride levels in groundwater at springs surrounding Lake Wingra. A team of citizen scientists, Friends of Lake Wingra volunteers, and Arboretum and Edgewood College staff monitor eight different springs each month. While there is not yet enough data to show long-term trends, five of the springs have reported chloride levels that exceed regulation limits, and one site has chloride levels that are considered toxic to aquatic organisms. Removing chloride from freshwater systems is difficult, but mitigation strategies such minimizing salt use are effective. Thank you to all our citizen scientists and partners who help monitor these springs year-round! #madisonwi #uwmadison #waterquality #lakewingra #volunteermonitoring #citizenscience

If you're visiting the Arboretum, we recommend good shoe traction, and ice cleats if you have them. Trail conditions were icy yesterday before the snow squall. With warming and freezing temps and more snow in the forecast, icy trails are possible for while longer. #uwmadison #madisonwi #wiwx

Coming to the Arboretum later this year! Follow @madisonpublicartproject  for sneak peeks.
——
#Repost @madisonpublicartproject with @make_repost
・・・
🍁✨The artists William Grant Turnbull @paradigmforge and Laura Richards are designing in the studio this week for their upcoming project, “Canopy Understories”. Once completed, the sculptures will be on view later this year at the @uwarboretum 

🍃✨ In their artistic process, the artists use a broad survey of scanned herbarium specimens to gauge the variations in the growth pattern and venation in a given species. 

🍂✨They digitally enhance their scans to study the numerical relationships and angular branching patterns of the veins. The composited design builds a completely new leaf, that was ‘grown’ by the averages of the different specimens. 

🌿Stay tuned for more behind the scenes looks of the upcoming “Canopy Understories” project! 

📸 Photo: @paradigmforge 
-
#publicart #placemaking #madisonwi #madisonwisconsin #madisonpublicartproject #wisconsin #wisconsinarts #wisconsinoutdoors #danecountyarts #artswisconsin #contemporaryart #sculpture #industrialdesign #nature #leaf #onwisconsin #canopyunderstories

This winter the field staff is restoring oak woodland savanna in the Lost City Forest and at the Grady Tract. The first phase is removing dense growth of the nonnative shrubs and vines buckthorn, honeysuckle, and bittersweet. We use a large skid-steer with a forestry mower attachment and do this work when the ground is frozen to minimize soil disturbance. You may see this work and its results in a 10-acre area of the Lost City east of Teal Pond and in a 12- to 15-acre area in the Grady Tract. Removing invasive species opens the understory and allows more sunlight to reach the ground. We will use prescribed fire and add seed to help regenerate native savanna wildflowers, grasses, and oaks. Restoration also provides habitat for wildlife, including species of concern such as the redheaded woodpecker. Photos: 1. Lost City area after forestry mowing, 2. forestry mower in Lost City, 3. dense shrubs in Grady Tract before mowing, 4. mowed area in Grady Tract. Photos by Chris Kregel. #uwmadison #madisonwi #ecologicalrestoration #landcare

You can make a difference for our lakes in your own backyard! Native plants help soak up the rain and prevent flooding in our area. Now is the time to plan how you can add those deep roots to your yard. https://dnr.wisconsin.gov/topic/endangeredresources/nativeplants.html #SoakUpTheRain
Image Text: Arboretum UNIVERSITY OF VISCONSIN- MADISON #SoakUp #SoakUpTheRain TheRain Cultivate a yard with deep and grounded roots.

Description: The 2022 Winter Enrichment series begins soon! February topics include environmental justice and stewardship in a West Atlanta watershed, the beauty and diversity of prairies, the Arboretum Research Symposium, and ways to inspire people about plants at Longenecker Horticultural Gardens. The virtual lectures will be on Thursday mornings, February 3 through April 7, from 10 to 11:30 a.m. Register now, visit our series webpage for more information. Link in bio. You won't want to miss these talks!
Image Text: WINTER ENRICHMENT 2022 Thursdays, February 3 to April 10-11:30 a.m. February 3 Culture and Conservation: Black Communities Advancing Environmental Justice and Stewardship Dr. Na'Taki Osborne Jelks, West Atlanta Watershed Alliance February 10 All the Little Things Chris Helzer, The Nature Conservancy February 17 Arboretum Research Symposium February 24 Longenecker Horticultural Gardens: Connecting People, Plants, and Place David Stevens, UW Madison Arboretum For full series, visit arboretum.wisc.edu

Description: Escape from the snow by taking some time to learn about rain gardens this winter! You can make one of your own by planting native plants that soak up the rain and help prevent flooding in our area. https://www.ripple-effects.com/rainGardens #soakuptherain
Image Text: Arboretum UNIVERSIT WISCONSIN- MADISON #SoakUp #SoakUpTheRain TheRain NAva Lake Wingra gave you beautiful blooms-now it's your turn!

Description: Dane County Land & Water Resources Department invites all K–12 students in Dane County to participate in the 2022 Conservation Awareness Poster Contest. The theme is “Healthy Soil: Healthy Life.” This contest aims to connect youth with the natural world and encourages them to deepen their knowledge of soil as a living ecosystem and vital natural resource.
Image Text: CONSERVATION POSTER CONTEST All Dane County K-12 students are invited to create a hand-drawn poster sharing the importance of healthy soils for a chance to win prizes! HEALTHY SOIK HEALTHY FOR MORE INFORMATION & ENTRY FORMS, VISIT: LWRD.COUNTYOFDANE. M/POSTERCONTEST

What turns your garden green—nutrients—can also turn our lakes green! Keep nutrients out of our lakes and in your soil by composting any yard waste that hasn’t been collected. https://dnr.wisconsin.gov/topic/Recycling/compost.html. #LeafFreeStreets

Fill the Hill is here, and the flamingos are back! Join the feathered fun starting at 5 p.m. today, October 28, through 6 p.m. on October 29.

What started as a playful prank more than forty years ago is now one of the UW’s most treasured traditions. Every flamingo on Bascom Hill represents a gift someone has made to the UW during this period. Join in the flamingo fun at uwflamingos.com and make a gift to the Friends of the Arboretum fund (we're listed under Find Your Cause), which helps the Arboretum meet its most pressing needs. Link in bio.

And tomorrow, stay tuned for bird quiz posts throughout the day!
Image Text: W FILL THE HILL 2021

Description: As the morning fog lifts. #madisonwi #uwmadison #wiwx #prairie

This year's fall color has been slow to emerge. Although day length is the driving force behind color change in foliage, the dry summer combined with the warm fall thus far in the Madison area has resulted in patchy and somewhat lackluster color change. The Arboretum is currently approaching around 20 percent peak color with the expected peak still projected to occur during the fourth week of October.

When leaves enter our lakes, they contribute excess nutrients that can lead to unpleasant algae growth and harm wildlife. Keep leaves off the streets to prevent this from happening! If you live in Dane County, you can sign up to receive alerts 1–2 days before large rain events. More here: https://ripple-effects.com/Leaf-free-Streets. #LeafFreeStreets
Image Text: Arboretum UNIVERSITY VISCONSIN- -MADISON #LeafFreeStreets Don't leaf me hanging! Remove leaves from the street BEFORE it rains.

Description: Autumn hues in the Wisconsin Native Plant Garden #madisonwi #uwmadison #uwfall

Surprise sightings: butterfly-weed and lilac blooms in late September! A number of butterfly-weeds were planted in July in the new short prairie garden behind the Visitor Center. These plants established and grew quickly, and recently produced some flowers. Next year they should bloom at the typical time in early summer. (Purple love grass is blooming in the background). There are also a few lilacs producing blooms in Longenecker Horticultural Gardens. There is an Asiatic lilac variety called ‘Bloomerang’ that reblooms later in the season, but when common lilacs rebloom at this time of year they are reacting to drought stress. Stress-induced reblooms could affect flower production the following spring. #uwmadison #madisonwi #wiwx

When fall leaves wash into our lakes, they contribute excess nutrients that can lead to unpleasant algae growth and harm wildlife the following summer. Make sure you’re ready to recycle your leaves right, whether it’s by mulching them on your lawn or setting them out for pickup. https://ripple-effects.com/Leaf-free-Streets #LeafFreeStreets
Image Text: Arboretum UNIVERSIT VISCONSIN MADISON #LeafFreeStreets Keep our lakes clean for feathered friends! '

Description: Now is a great time to visit the prairies and savannas of the Arboretum. Check out the Grady Tract to explore its knolls and Greene Prairie. Plants you may encounter this time of year include blazing-star, rattlesnake master, yellow false foxglove, white sage, swamp milkweed, and more. Much of the plant diversity in Greene Prairie is attributed to Henry Greene himself: he hand planted more than 130 species from 1942 through the early 1960s. #wisconsin #UWMadison #nativeplants #prairies #oaksavannas #ecologicalrestoration
Happy summer! #madisonwi #uwmadison #nativeplants

Tick season is in full swing. A collaborative research project called @thetickapp is focused on understanding how people’s activities and practices impact their potential exposure to ticks and Lyme disease. Participants can tell researchers about tick encounters and submit photos of ticks for identification. The Tick App is available on Google Play or the App Store.

Milkweed is emerging at the Arboretum, and a new season of monitoring has begun! Director Karen Oberhauser first spotted milkweed outside the Visitor Center on May 7, and @mlmpcitsci volunteers started monitoring this area last week. In 2020, volunteers monitored 8,024 plants and reported the presence of 281 eggs and 69 caterpillars at 4 sites in the Arboretum. For those interested in becoming a volunteer, MLMP will be hosting a virtual training on June 12, with an optional in-person component at the Arboretum on June 13. Click the link in @mlmpcitsci profile to register.

Check out this upcoming training at the Arboretum, with our partners at @mlmpcitsci. #Repost @mlmpcitsci with @make_repost
・・・
Don't forget - we have an upcoming virtual MLMP Training on Saturday, June 12th! If you'd like to purchase an MLMP kit with your training, be sure to sign up by May 31st. 🦋

MLMP kits include monarch life cycle cards, MLMP larval ID clipboard, thermometer, hand lens, Milkweed Monarchs and More field guide, a pencil, and MLMP drawstring field bag.

To register for this event, head to the link in our bio.

#monarchconservation #savethemonarchs #citizenscience

Description: It was a productive prescribed fire season at the Arboretum. The fire crew burned units of Curtis and Greene Prairie, outlying properties, and oak savanna restoration sites in the Grady Tract. The crew accomplished many goals, including reducing brush and dead fuels, burning garlic mustard and other invasive species, and improving wildlife habitat. Three fires also met research goals. Next steps are enjoying the growth of native vegetation and, in fall, collecting seed. #uwmadison #wisconsin #rxfire #ecologicalrestoration #fireecology

Starting last fall, Arboretum staff began to develop a children’s activity area in Longenecker Horticultural Gardens. This project has transformed an underutilized part of the gardens into a functional space for visitors. Families are encouraged to explore pathways, discover plants and animals, and create nature art together. The children’s activity area is located in the southeast corner of the gardens, between the service buildings and entrance to Gallistel Woods. Many thanks to David Stevens, Zane Fuller, and Jennifer Mitchell for their vision and work. #uwmadison #outdooreducation #natureplay #getoutside

Description: In 1952, with Aldo Leopold’s help, Faville Prairie was designated as Wisconsin's third State Natural Area. The Arboretum and Madison Audubon Society manage Faville’s land care, and the staff have put a lot of work into restoring the remnant prairie. Last week, they did a prescribed burn of about 50 acres. This followed restoration work this winter using a forestry mower to clear 15–18 acres of brush that had encroached over the years. A lot of unique native plant species grow here and should thrive this spring! Many grassland bird species also use this site as habitat. #ecologicalrestoration #rxfire
Join @uw_socialjusticehub and @sustainuw next week for a panel discussion April 19 at 7 p.m. about outdoor accessibility and inclusive experiences. Info on participating is on the third image.

Day of the Badger is here! Looking for ways to participate? Share what you love about the Arboretum in the comments or post your story using the hashtags #UWArboretum and #DayoftheBadger. And if you can, support the Arboretum by giving to the Friends of the Arboretum fund (we're listed under Causes). Gifts help sustain the Arboretum’s work and maintain the UW’s excellence in education. Every story, every gift matters. Click the link in our profile to show your support today.

Oak savanna restoration work continues at the Grady Tract (south of the Beltline). To help this highly diverse site, the land care crew has been removing various species of non-desirable shrubs and trees. Chainsaws, forestry mowers, and tractors all help with the removal process. Before the first snow last fall, the crew seeded restoration areas with dry, mesic, and savanna plant species. These ongoing restoration efforts help re-establish and increase abundance of native plant and animal communities. #madisonwi #uwmadison #ecologicalrestoration

Are you interested in learning more about monarch biology and getting involved with community science through the Monarch Larva Monitoring Project (MLMP)? Then register today to join the Monarch Joint Venture and the UW–Madison Arboretum in a virtual @mlmpcitsci training on March 27: ow.ly/hr0R50DIWn8

A friendly reminder to please stay on designated trails at the Arboretum. We have had many reports of off-trail use this winter—such as in this photo, where a trail has been made going past a "this is not a trail" sign. Going off trail compacts snow and ice, damaging plants—even in winter—and disrupting habitat for overwintering animals. Thanks for helping protect the Arboretum and all that lives here.

Even with the Visitor Center closed, you can still enjoy outdoor learning. Stroll through Longenecker Horticultural Gardens to find informative signs about plants, animals, and winter ecology. See if you can find all eleven signs – topics include voles, crabapples, dark-eyed juncos, and more. #madisonwi #uwmadison #winterwildlife  #environmentaleducation

Like spring, fall provides the Arboretum with another opportunity to conduct prescribed burns, as plants are dormant and burn conditions are favorable. Prescribed fire can replicate a natural process that helps us conserve and restore fire-dependent habitats like prairies and oak savannas. The Arboretum land care crew used prescribed fire at Oliver prairie on November 17, reducing brush by 50 percent and fine dead fuels by 90 percent. #rxfire #prescribedfire #prairies #wisconsinstatenaturalarea #ecologicalrestoration

Today is GivingTuesday,  a global day of giving and unity. This year you can support the Arboretum by giving to the Friends of the Arboretum fund. We welcome and appreciate gifts in any amount.  Gifts support the Arboretum’s most pressing needs and help us keep working to restore land, advance research, conserve biodiversity, and serve you as an outdoor destination and learning center. https://jumpstart.supportuw.org/campaigns/arboretum-4

We are delighted to announce that the first phase of the Curtis Pond project has been completed and the trails in Curtis Prairie have reopened. One major highlight for visitors is the new trail on the south side of the pond, creating a full prairie loop. There are many ecological benefits to this project as well. As the restorations grow and fill in and the stormwater infrastructure works as designed, there will be a healthier prairie to enjoy and cleaner water flowing downstream. We ask that you please stay on trails at all times to protect the restorations as they get established. Happy trails! #madisonwi #uwmadison #ecologicalrestoration #stormwatermanagement

We would like to introduce Charlotte Francoeur, a microbiology graduate student who is working with the UW–Madison Arboretum through the @wiscience public service fellow program. She is fascinated by microbes and the many ways they influence the environment and our lives. For her project, she is making a zine (a small self-published magazine) and giving a talk in the winter enrichment series. These will explore the wonders of microbes in the Arboretum and beyond. The zine will be beautifully illustrated by Lindsey Leigh and freely available on the Arboretum website in spring. #madisonwi #uwmadison #microbelife

Over the past few months, the field staff collected seed from approximately 100 different plant species throughout the Arboretum’s prairies, forests and wetlands. This seed is threshed through a seed mill and added to a seed mix. Once the mix is complete, field staff will redistribute the seed in restoration areas to create more native habitats. #madisonwi #uwmadison #ecologicalrestoration

The American chestnut (Castea dentata) was once the most common tree in Appalachian Mountain forests, but in the early twentieth century it was devastated by the chestnut blight, a fungal species from Asia. Their native range extends from the Gulf Coast states all the way into Maine, so they are adaptable hardy trees. Four American chestnuts (as well as two Alleghany chinquapins, a related species) in the Longenecker Horticultural Gardens collection are suited to Wisconsin’s climate of cold winters and hot humid summers. And since we are outside the chestnuts’ native range, the blight has not reached our trees. Chestnuts provide ample food for the wildlife of the Arboretum every fall, including turkeys, crows, and blue jays.

The Flamingos are back . . . and this year, they’re virtual! For the first time you can support the Arboretum (under Find Your Cause), from now until 6 p.m. on October 23. We welcome and appreciate gifts in any amount. Give $75 or more to receive a flamingo-adorned mask. Gifts support the Arboretum’s most pressing needs and help us keep working to restore land, advance research, conserve biodiversity, and serve you as an outdoor destination and learning center. Join in the flamingo fun from anywhere in the world at uwflamingos.com.  #UWFlamingos

Happy Homecoming week Badgers! Fill the Hill 2020 is all virtual this year—and these flamingos are virtually unflappable! Join the feathered fun October 21–23. This year you can support the Arboretum by giving to the Friends of the Arboretum fund (we're listed under Causes). Follow link in bio. #UWFlamingos

Description: Last weekend Arboretum staff and friends – in coordination with @partyfortheplanet.wi organized by @henryvilaszoo – planted a jack pine honoring this year’s 50th anniversary of Earth Day. The smallest of Wisconsin’s pine species, jack pines can reach 50 to 70 feet tall. The rare Kirtland's warbler nests only in young jack pine stands in Michigan, Wisconsin, and Ontario, Canada. Jack pines were once widespread in Wisconsin, but acreage is decreasing due to habitat conversion and climate change. Visit this newest addition to the pinetum in Longenecker Horticultural Gardens and enjoy the beauty and variety of other species of pine trees as well. #madisonwi #uwmadison #conifers #wibirds

Summer is always a busy time for Arboretum research, and this year was no exception. We usually hire undergraduate students to assist with field work but couldn’t this year due to COVID. Ten Arboretum staff members pitched in to help research specialist Christy Lowney collect data for a study about how the timing of prescribed fire affects oak savanna restoration. The research began in 2019 in collaboration with researchers at Grand Valley State University. Summer data collection is an important part of monitoring for changes following the prescribed fires conducted last year in spring (dormant season) and summer (growing season). #madisonwi #uwmadison #uwresearch #rxfire #ecologicalrestoration

Native thistles are important for many insect species, including the endangered rusty-patched bumble bee (RPBB), because they bloom between peak summer flowers and fall-blooming goldenrods and asters. Bumble bees have an annual life cycle, and the gynes—future queens—that emerge in late summer are the only bees in a colony to survive until the next spring. They feed briefly and mate, then dig into loose soil to overwinter. Does your garden have late summer and early fall flowers to support them? In these two photos, taken at the same location, RPBB gynes forage on pasture thistle (Cirsium discolor). One was taken on August 29, 2018 (by Susan Carpenter), the other on August 29, 2020 (by volunteer Judy Cardin). Perhaps they are grandmother and granddaughter!

With autumn right around the corner, the field staff have been busy collecting seed. After a hot summer working on invasive species, this is a welcome change. The staff have collected seed from many different species—from early spring ephemerals to summer bloomers like purple prairie clover. By the end of October the crew will have a good amount of seed collected and ready to add to restorations this fall before it snows. #sawtoothsunflower #liatris #prairie

We’ve had many reports of tree climbing and dogs at the Arboretum this spring and want to share a reminder that these are not allowed on the grounds. Several trees have suffered broken limbs, likely from climbing, and this can threaten the health of the tree. We don’t want people with broken limbs, either! For the safety and enjoyment of visitors and protection of all that lives here, please follow the visitor etiquette guidelines listed on our website. #madisonwi #uwmadison #urbannature
Our land care staff snapped this shot of a sandhill crane making the most of a perch usually frequented by a red-tailed hawk. #madisonwi #uwmadison #urbanwildlife #birdseyeview

In order to understand and protect species it is important to monitor and track their migrations. @journeynorthorg is a citizen science platform that relies on community members to help track these species.  Community members contribute to over 50,000 sightings per year! And this amazing organization is located at the UW-Arboretum (way to go Madison!). Head to your yard, patio, or local park to look for some of the species they monitor. Then head to their website to report your sighting! Take a picture outside, or of your computer, post it, and tag us @PartyforthePlant.Wi for one (1) prize entry!  Check out journeynorth.org for more information. #partyfortheplanetwi

The @uwarboretum goes gold! 🌟 🌱 Thanks to improvements in energy use (like installing smart power strips), purchasing practices (like buying recycled paper and using SWAP), and waste management (like adding compost), the Arboretum Visitor Center has received our Green Office “Gold Level” certification. Last summer they were receiving their first bronze-level presentation; this spring, they’re a leader of the pack!

On a warm sunny day like today, you still might find a few bumble bees lingering on goldenrods and asters. Most bumble bees you can see now are male common eastern bumble bees (Bombus impatiens), but if you're very, very lucky you might spot a future queen. 
Art by @chase_prairie , science communications fellow.

You can do citizen science anywhere, including your own garden. Jessica Ross, citizen science coordinator, shares some tips. Drawn by @chase_prairie, the 2019–20 Arboretum Science Communication Fellow. #madisonwi #uwmadison #scicomm #citizenscience
How much do bees love goldenrod? Multiply by 100s of plants! #madisonwi #uwmadison #fall #prairieplants
Morning, before the sunshine #madisonwi #uwmadison #wiwx #fog

The land care crew started restoring Skunk Cabbage Wetlands in winter 2016–17. (Scroll pics to see the results!) @christopherkregel recently shared a project update. The area has a spectacular skunk cabbage population early in the spring but had been infested with large buckthorn trees and bittersweet vines. The crew cut and cut and cut, and they used the tractor to winch out the biggest buckthorns. They followed up to remove herbaceous invasive species, they seeded with seed collected by hand, and they used prescribed fire in the site as well. Here are some of Chris’s before and after photos (plus one he didn’t take), although, he says “Pictures don't do it justice. But this has been my and our proudest project to date.” Great work crew! #madisonwi #uwmadison #ecologicalrestoration #wetlands

An America toad in the Native Plant Garden. This is Wisconsin’s only toad species. They can be found in every county, in habitats ranging from woodlands and wetlands to fields and prairies, as well as gardens and parks. Their skin is adapted to retain moisture, so they can live farther from water than other frogs. They will return to water to breed and lay eggs. #madisonwi #uwmadison #toads
Rare sight: a walking stick takes the stairs. Also cool: learning they are called Phasmids. #madisonwi #uwmadison #insects

Get ready to get growing! Our native gardening conference will help you learn to plant, maintain, and improve beautiful, sustainable native plant landscapes. Register soon – last year we reached capacity in late August. Link in profile. #nativeplants #pollinators #wildlife #gardening

Science can be done by anyone! Learn skills you can use anywhere at our Citizen Science Open House on August 10, from 12–4 p.m. Participate in hands-on learning activities, explore citizen science projects at interactive tables, take part in a bioblitz. We’ll have activities, information, and opportunities for all experience levels. All ages welcome (children must be accompanied by an adult). More info:

So many wildflowers in bloom! Find compass-plant, hoary vervain, butterfly-weed, lead-plant, bee balm, and more in the native plant garden, prairies, and savannas. Learn more about them on a garden tour – the next one is all about plants for pollinators, on Wednesday, July 17, at 7 p.m. with Susan Carpenter.

A big welcome to the #MandelaFellows! Today these leaders are here on a tour with Longenecker Horticultural Gardens curator David Stevens. We’re excited to be a community partner and learn from and work with them over the coming weeks. #YALIatUW #YALI2019
Sometimes, if you’re really lucky, you get to watch cranes dance #madisonwi #uwmadison #wildlife #sandhillcranes

A big thank you to @americorpsnccc Cedar team 3 for all their hard work, curiosity, and enthusiasm. They’ve been in Madison since early May and spent several weeks at the Arboretum, working with our staff to improve the trails, gardens, and natural areas. It’s a great experience for them and for us! Their service has a lasting impact at the Arboretum and in the community. We wish these young leaders the very best as they move on in a few days to their next assignment. #madisonwi #uwmadison #americorpsnccc
wee monarch larva #madisonwi #uwmadison #monarchbutterflies

Late spring native plants are blooming in the prairies and savannas. Learn about native plant identification and gardening practices in the Native Plant Garden and look for these plants in their natural environments. Pictured: spiderwort, wild columbine, wild lupine, wild geranium, prairie phlox, golden alexanders. As always, please respect the ecosystems by staying on trails, and refrain from touching or picking flowers and plant material. 👏🏼⭐️ #madisonwi #uwmadison #nativeplants #wisconsin #lovenature

There’s good birdwatching here – if you can find them in the fresh foliage. 😊 Many species are breeding, nesting, singing, and foraging. You might see bluebirds at the nesting boxes, cedar waxwings feeding on crabapples, blue-gray gnatcatchers hopping on branches looking for insects, and northern flickers foraging on the ground. Listen for the distinctive calls of catbirds and cardinals. Please follow good birding etiquette – don’t disturb or crowd birds, and always stay on trails. 👏🏼⭐️ #madisonwi #uwmadison #uwspring #birding #birds
A lone sandhill crane takes shelter near the visitor center as a spring thunderstorm rolls in. #madisonwi #uwmadison #wiwx

Horticulture garden bloom update: Magnolias are past peak, but a few trees still have good bloom display that should last through the weekend and into next week. The majority of crabapples are in bud or blooming. Peak bloom should begin this weekend and go through next weekend. Due to last year’s wet and cloudy growing season and the winter’s extreme cold, the lilac display will not be as robust as usual. About 40% of the collection will have few to no blooms. The rest of the lilac collection is either in bloom or will begin to bloom soon. Peak bloom should start this weekend and continue through next weekend. As always, bloom times and duration are weather dependent. #madisonwi #uwmadison #horticulture #uwspring

While a few lilacs and crabapples have started to bloom, the cool temperatures and cloudy days have slowed progress. Some of the late-flowering magnolias are in bloom. Sun and warmth should help the lilacs and crabapples along, and the crabapples are likely to have more blooms this weekend than the lilacs, but substantial bloom for both is still a week away (if weather stays warm and sunny). #madisonwi #uwmadison #uwspring #wiwx #horticulture

Blooms! But first: Spring is a busy time of year, especially when the spectacular flowering trees and shrubs bloom in Longenecker Horticultural Gardens. We’d like to remind visitors that dogs/pets, picnics, drones, and tree climbing are not allowed (more about etiquette and road safety at the link in our profile). While you enjoy the Arboretum, your cooperation helps protect all that lives here. On to the bloom update! The magnolias that were in full bloom are now fading. More are blooming now and others should start in the next week. Cherries should be in bloom through the weekend. Lilacs are just beginning and will bloom more fully in 7–10 days. Crabapples are leafing out and should also bloom in 7–10 days. Weather affects bloom times and duration, so these timelines can change. #uwmadison #madisonwi #uwspring

Who’s ready to garden?! Native plants are beautiful and have many ecological benefits. Come shop the Friends of the Arboretum Native Plant Sale on May 11, 9 a.m.–2 p.m.. More than 200 species of wildflowers, grasses, trees, and shrubs will be available, and experts will be on hand to answer questions. Link to plant lists and other sale information in profile. #nativeplants

Bloom update: About 40 percent of the magnolia collection is in bloom. Once flowers are open, they are easily damaged by cold. If we get the mid-20s forecasted for overnight Saturday, all the open flowers will wither. Some magnolias are just starting to bloom, and the mid- and late-season trees haven’t started to bloom yet. The cold may damage those just opening, and we hope there will be little damage to those not yet flowering. So the good news is that about 40% of the collection still has potential to bloom after Saturday’s weather. 
Cherries have only a light bloom this year. The extreme cold in late January killed most of the flower buds, and those in bloom will likely lose flowers due to cold this weekend. 
Crabapples and lilacs are not yet blooming and will likely come through Saturday’s cold without damage. #madisonwi #uwmadison #uwspring #wiwx

In this indoor/outdoor class, you’ll walk the Arboretum’s bluebird trail and learn about bluebirds, their behavior, their decline, and restoration efforts. Instructor: Sylvia Marek, Arboretum naturalist. Register by April 23 via events calendar (link in profile). #uwmadison #environmentaleducation
Don’t fret friends! It always snows in April. #madisonwi #uwmadison #uwspring #wiwx

Skunk Cabbage abounds in the wetlands named for the native plant, which is one of the first to emerge here in early spring, usually in late February to early March. The plant gets its name from the stinky odor it emits to attract pollinators like flies and gnats. It is also one of only a few plants that generates its own heat to melt away surrounding snow—a process called thermogenesis. The speckled purple spathe (modified leaf) and flower heads (inside the spathes) emerge first, while the large leaves develop later in spring. #madisonwi #uwmadison #uwspring #winativeplants
The remains of a deer that had died in the tall grasses of the native plant garden during the winter and been covered by snow. The dried vegetation concealed it until today’s prescribed fire.
A sure sign of spring! We burned several sections of the native plant garden today. #rxfire #nativeplants

The snow is gone from Curtis Prairie, mud and puddles remain. Bluebirds, red-winged blackbirds, and sandhill cranes have returned to the area. New plant growth and insects will soon emerge. Happy spring! #madisonwi #uwmadison #uwspring

Phenology—the study of periodic occurrences in nature—is both art and science, practiced for millennia across cultures and regions. Learn about different approaches, and even invent your own. Register by April 2 at arboretum.wisc.edu.
Scenes from the thaw #madisonwi #uwmadison
Almost-spring fog. One week til equinox #madisonwi #uwmadison  #wiwx

We’re decorating for tomorrow’s volunteer recognition party. There are more than 900 triangles - one for every person who gave their time and efforts to the Arboretum in 2018. A big thank you to all of them! #uwmadison #volunteersrock

Spring Trail Pond, off Nakoma Road, is a great place to see winter birds. The open-water spring-fed pond attracts waterfowl as well as tree-dwelling birds like cardinals, chickadees, fox sparrows, and red-bellied woodpeckers. (Fox sparrows usually winter south, but a few stay over where there’s enough water and food.) #madisonwi #uwmadison #birding #winter

White-breasted nuthatches overwinter in Wisconsin and are often seen at bird feeders. They are nicknamed the “upside down bird” because they frequently work their way headfirst down tree trunks looking for insects in the bark. Nuthatches often forage with other birds like chickadees and downy woodpeckers, relying on the other birds’ alarm calls so they can be less vigilant about predators and focus more on finding food. #madisonwi #uwmadison
It’s treacherous out there if your trying to get around. But it’s also beautiful. Stay safe, and today we’ll bring the scenery to you. #madisonwi #uwmadison #wiwx

Our land care crew is spread out clearing ice from sidewalks and parking lots. Restoration, road clearing, scraping ice to keep visitors safe, and so much more – they do it all with dedication and skill. They are the best.

Walking through the prairie in fall and winter, you might see some of these swellings, called galls, on plant stems. A gall on a goldenrod stem is caused by the goldenrod gall fly, which lays its eggs near emerging goldenrod stems in the spring. After hatching, the fly larva makes its way into the plant tissues and starts to feed, resulting in the formation of the gall. The gall provides shelter and food for the larva through the winter until it emerges as an adult fly in the spring. The larvae are not completely safe in the galls, however, as they are eaten by small birds and wasp larvae. The gall fly larva’s ability to survive winter temperatures and its interactions with predators and the host plant have made it a common organism for biochemical and ecological research.
When roof drain spout meets little bluestem #nativeplants

Wildflower blooms and leaves have withered, but fall and winter plants display distinctive seedheads. Seeds spread by wind, water, animals, and sometime fire. They are an important food source for animals, and stalks offer shelter for insects, birds, and small mammals. Seed dispersal allows plants to spread to areas with less competition and helps maintain species diversity. Pictured are Canada goldenrod, aster, purple giant hyssop, Joe-pye weed, sawtooth sunflower, and thistle. #madisonwi #uwmadison #fall #nativeplants
First snow #madisonwi #wiwx

Goldenrod is often blamed for late summer and fall allergies, however the real culprit is usually ragweed. Goldenrod has heavy sticky pollen, which can only be pollinated by insects, whereas ragweed pollen is released into the air and carried by the wind. Pollinators such as birds, bees, and monarchs rely on goldenrod for food in the fall, when most other flowers have already gone to seed. #madisonwi #uwmadison #uwfall #nativeplants #pollinators
Clouds over Curtis Prairie feather like tall grasses #madisonwi #uwmadison #uwfall #prairie #wisconsin

As we await fall color, there is still a lot to see in Longenecker Horticultural Gardens if you look closely. Many pollinators are attracted to the showy seven-son flower, including monarchs and hummingbirds. Hydrangeas attract bumblebees, honeybees, and wasps. The colorful crabapple fruit found on trees this time of year will persist through the winter and help feed birds. Bright orange Magnolia seeds emerge from lumpy pods when ripe. With this post we introduce Heidi (@heidimichelleportfolio), our student communications assistant, who took the photos and helped research and write the post. #uwmadison #madisonwi #horticulture #pollinators

Blooms! Now that we have your attention, we’d like to add a few reminders: pets, picnics, alcohol, tree climbing, hammocks, and drones are not allowed (see more at arboretum.wisc.edu/visit/etiquette/). And please always stay on trails. But don’t let this dampen your enthusiasm – your cooperation helps minimize the human impact and protect all that lives here at the Arboretum. Thank you!

We started prescribed fire season this year by burning two hill prairies at outlying properties. Prescribed fire mimics a natural process that helps clear invasive species and restores plant diversity. #rxfire (📷: @christopherkregel) #Repost @christopherkregel with @get_repost
